1) Get httpd.conf working as required on stage 03/04
2) Setup syncing (see below)
3) Modify CMS publication target

We will outline final steps that we expect to take before completing this ticket.

---

Previous email, also see attached diagram:

---

Please find attached a diagram (attached) illustrating how I saw the new staging servers fitting in (btw. I have no strong preference to them being used this way, this just what I sort of expected based on previous emails)

I realise that one of the main criteria you are hoping to use it for is testing of the load balancers and Apache configs (which will be immensely useful) and therefore you possibly weren't seeing them as part of the live (everyday) publication workflow, maybe you were? once again happy to use them either way.

Obviously if we have a static / self contained website it is very easy to just place it on the staging servers, see if it works and then copy it across to the live servers if it does.

However when we have a new section of the main site (like /get-involved/volunteering) that is intrinsically tied to other pages on the main site / shares components with the live CMS and utilises feeds running on the live CMS it is not quite so simple to separate out the site to a separate server.

The approach I have outlined in the diagram below (and in my email last week) re-routes the current publication from "CMS to web01" to "CMS to staging server01" this gives us an opportunity to limit the RSYNC (completely, by file type or by section) between the staging environment and web01 and therefore view the site on the staging servers first.

The downside of this approach is that staging 01 and 02 become part of the publication workflow and therefore if they are unavailable publication will break.

A complete shutdown of the rsync will also hold up everyday editorial publication, therefore I suggest we look at an intelligent way of limiting what is automatically rynced and what has to be pushed by hand.

I think we probably also need to decide which of these the new servers is really (or most importantly) for:

- testing out config changes to Apache and/or the load balancer and Akamai
- testing out standalone new sites
- a real time mirror of the live environment that all changes have first to pass though (question around delays to editorial publication and how we deal with these)
- limiting the automatic syncing to the live environment of certain kinds of global files (css / js etc.)
- limiting the automatic syncing to the live environment of certain sections
- limiting the automatic syncing to the live environment  completely in the case of a relaunch (question around delays to editorial publication and how we deal with these)

The one big question that needs clarifying I think is whether we expect these servers to be part of the live everyday production workflow (if they are, we can't just turn them off / reboot them at will) or do they simply hold a 'clone' of the existing published site (ie. whatever is on web01 although that does imply they are only useful for testing config changes and not 'staging').

I have included on the diagram our existing / internal dev/staging environment for completeness, what is important to note here is that the editorial content on this server is not the same as the live content, it is a periodic clone of the content held in the CMS, which makes it useful for development/testing but not for handling a real time staging->production workflow.

There looks like some overlap with this ticket. Do you mind adding any extra time you think is reasonable (if any) and we can close it.

comments.value: I am consistently unable to view the alt text on images in our website whenever I view it in IE7. I can see alt text on other sites, so it's not that my browser has alt text suppressed. We do need alt text to be visible for obvious accessibility reasons - can you investigate? Thanks
Setting to high.

Alt text is not supposed to be visible when you see the image itself. If we have alt text on the images (and we do), those who need alt text for navigation, will see it. There's a slight confusion w/ implementation in older versions of Internet Explorer (it confuses tooltips/title tags with alt text). Here's what the specification says:

"The alt attribute specifies alternate text that is rendered when the image cannot be displayed (see below for information on how to specify alternate text ). User agents must render alternate text when they cannot support images, they cannot support a certain image type or when they are configured not to display images."

http://www.456bereastreet.com/archive/200604/alt_text_is_an_alternative_not_a_tooltip/
Hmm, I’m still not sure here. Why can I see alt text on e.g. bbc.co.uk but not on our site? Is alt text actually coded to be invisible except to screen readers users on our site?

Here's a fragment of code from the BBC home page: There is an image with alt text, "Homes Under the Hammer", wrapped inside a link with title, "Visit the Homes Under the Hammer page". The alt text is what is displayed when the picture cannot be seen (such as with a screen reader). The title text, which in this case is associated not with the image but with the link is being used as a call to action associated with that link. Looking again at the BBC home page, some links have the title text on the link and some don't, cf. (in case you get a chance to look at this while it's still up, it's the "Weird & Wonderful" link in the central column) So, back to london2012.com, we do not currently add title tags to links and we do not by default add title tags to images either--although we do in some cases. See for example http://www.london2012.com/photos/search.php, where we have added the title tag to the image (although not, as in the case of the BBC home page, to the link): Here, we appear to have added a title tag and just copied the text of the alt tag. however, this is not something that we have done for all images. In summary, the alt tag is an accessibility requirement, while the title tag is a convenience to all users, but I don't believe it is a requirement from an accessibility point of view. We have already added the title tag (using the text of the alt tag) in some contexts, but not in all. We could probably add it elsewhere, if needed, although some work would be required to investigate where it was needed and to add the necessary code. I think that's clear in my head now (thanks to Janos), I hope it's a bit clearer to you as well :-)
Happy to close this – thanks for your explanation!

It probably enough to parse the logs on web01 and out the output the results as a HTML page inside a password protected dir (*) under the doc root ie. /www/html/new/london2012/404report/ 

As for the report itself, would be good to separate out:

- Direct 404 requests : these are outside our control
- Requests form robots:  also outside our control
- 404 with referring pages that we serve (ie. broken links on our pages) : these we /can/ do something about
- But excluded from the above should be any requests from the 'lookahead engine' of the buggy version of IE8 (or similar). 

In short the list of errors should be pretty small and limited to one we can actually fix ie. broken links in web pages we are serving. No harm in listing the rest but these should be separated out as they are outside of our control.

The point of this file is we can easily spot any error or broken link introduced into the site, a huge list of vague 404's is near useless, with or without referrers/agents (or at the very least will require a lot of manual effort to digest / investigate each time we look at it)

* a .htaccess file with the following in it will do the trick: (login/pass is any previous 2012 password combination ie. stratford/design or you could add new entry to /var/www/.htpasswd)

AuthName "Restricted Area New"
AuthType Basic
AuthUserFile /var/www/.htpasswd
AuthGroupFile /dev/null
require valid-user

We will take the report in whatever form is easiest for you send. Email is fine. Another possibility is to output the results as a HTML page inside a password protected directory on the site.

As for the report itself, it would be good to separate out:

- Direct 404 requests
- Requests from robots
- Requests from the 'lookahead engine' of the buggy version of IE8
- 404s with referring pages that we serve (ie. broken links on our pages)

The first three we cannot do much about, so although it would be useful to get some numbers, it is probably less useful to get a detailed breakdown.
